citation.article-title: Marinomonas primoryensis sp. nov., a novel psychrophile isolated from coastal sea-ice in the Sea of Japan.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Marinomonas primoryensis sp. nov.
Marinomonas primoryensis (pri.mo.ry.en′sis. N.L. fem. adj. primoryensis pertaining to Primorye, Far-Eastern region of Russia).
Cells are Gram-negative, strictly aerobic, 0·4–0·6 μm wide, 1·6–1·8 μm long and motile by a single polar unsheathed flagellum.
Oxidase reaction is positive or weakly positive.
Sodium ions are required for growth; grows in 1–6 % NaCl.
Growth occurs at 4–30 °C but not at 35 °C.
Transparent colonies are formed, which become yellowish after 36–48 h incubation.
Pigment diffuses slightly into the agar.
Lipase, caseinase, DNase, gelatinase and amylase are not produced.
Negative for arginine dihydrolase, nitrate reduction and acid production from carbohydrates.

Utilizes d-glucose, maltose, mannitol, glycerol, N-acetylglucosamine, l-asparagine, l-lysine, l-methionine, citrate, malate, m-hydroxybenzoate, acetate and succinate; does not utilize arabinose, valine or l-glutamic acid.
The predominant fatty acids are C16 : 0, C16 : 1ω9c and C18 : 1ω7c.
The DNA G+C content is 45·3–45·6 mol%.
Isolated from coastal sea-ice in Amursky Bay of the Sea of Japan.
